statement.text: Iliac vein stenting treats iliofemoral venous obstruction from May-Thurner syndrome or post-thrombotic disease, using dedicated venous stents with IVUS guidance to restore outflow and significantly improve symptoms in properly selected patients.

explanation.intuition: Just like stenting a blocked artery, you can stent a blocked vein to open it up. The iliac veins (in the pelvis) are commonly affected by either external compression or old blood clots, and stents can restore normal drainage.
explanation.key_insight: IVUS (intravascular ultrasound) is essential for venous stenting - it reveals obstruction not visible on venography. Dedicated venous stents are preferred over arterial stents due to different radial force and flexibility requirements.
explanation.technical_details: Indications: May-Thurner syndrome, post-thrombotic iliofemoral obstruction, chronic venous insufficiency with outflow obstruction. Technique: femoral or popliteal access, IVUS to assess stenosis (>50% reduction), dedicated venous stent sized to vessel diameter. Stent types: Wallstent, VICI, Venovo, Abre (venous-specific). IVUS criteria: >50% area reduction is significant. Patency: 1-year 80-90% for non-thrombotic, 70-80% for post-thrombotic. Anticoagulation: typically 3-6 months post-stent.

primary_sources.title: Journal of Vascular Surgery: Venous and Lymphatic Disorders

clinical_pearls: IVUS is mandatory - venography underestimates stenosis by 30-40%
Use dedicated venous stents, not arterial stents
>50% area reduction on IVUS is significant obstruction
